awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Predictive Modeling of Maize Metabolism
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop and test predictive mathematical models of the chemical reactions (metabolism) by which maize (corn) transforms the sugars produced during photosynthesis into compounds such as starch that are stored in the seeds. The goal is to understand starch metabolism better and provide the means for enhancing food production. This study will reveal fundamental principles of metabolic function and dynamics, and provide interdisciplinary training (in mathematical modeling, genetic engineering and metabolic biochemistry) to students engaged in this project.

Starchy endosperm (SE) is the major site of carbohydrate and protein storage in cereals, but atypical constraints complicate detailed resolution of the system. These include a steady state carbon dioxide level of essentially zero, coincident with energy-expensive breakdown and re-synthesis of building blocks prior to storage polymer formation. A major question in SE metabolism is how ATP is generated to support starch and protein synthesis, and how the photo-assimilate is divided between catabolic and anabolic pathways. This project will expand upon existing flux models to account for bio-energetic parameters, and probe the system by directed genetic modifications that impair specific metabolic nodes. Metabolite levels and flux maps will be compared between SE from unaltered and mutant lines. These data will be applied to refine the mathematical models and test hypotheses of how the system diverts chemical resources for storage compound accumulation.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we advanced maize systems biology by developing predictive models for maize metabolism and computational tools to support these models.

Intellectual Merit

We first developed and analyzed an updated genome-scale stoichiometric model (GSM) for maize. Our model, MaizeGSM4.4k, is an up-to-date, fully compartmentalized GSM curated from information in the databases CornCyc and MaizeCyc. At the time of its construction, it contained more unique reactions than other published maize GSMs. We used MaizeGSM4.4k to perform flux balance analysis of maize endosperm metabolism, together with experimental metabolomic data from this project. This goal of this analysis was to predict altered Gln uptake and amino acid biosynthesis in pyruvate phosphate dikinase (PPDK)-deficient endosperm. Our analysis demonstrated that PPDK provides flexibility for ADP-glucose synthesis across compartments. We also developed a computational framework to integrate time-resolved transcriptomics data from the literature into MaizeGSM4.4k for investigating the temporal dynamics of zein protein accumulation.

We developed three algorithms to support the models in this work. First, we developed a network reduction algorithm, NetRed that creates compact, biologically meaningful maps of carbon flow in large metabolic models. This algorithm was motivated by the need to perform a condensed representation, visualization and interpretation of the outputs of genome-scale FBA. Toward this goal, we equipped NetRed with the ability to handle genome-scale metabolic networks. Next, we complemented NetRed by developing a tool NetFlow that isolates carbon flow in genome-scale metabolic networks by simulating isotope labeling in the networks. Finally, we developed a new approach to isotope-assisted metabolic flux analysis (iMFA). Previous to this work, iMFA suffered in the speed and reliability of convergence. We remedied this by casting the MFA problem as an equality-constrained nonlinear program (NLP) with equality constraints constructed from the iMFA model equations, and solved it by using the General Algebraic Modeling System (GAMS), an algebraic modeling language (AML) with state-of-the-art optimization solvers. This new approach improved the robustness and scalability of iMFA.

Broader Impact

Together, our contributions advance maize systems biology by providing models and computational tools to the community. Our results are expected to benefit food and fuel production from maize. This project trained 5 graduate students (Ph.D. and master's) and several undergraduates, in addition to creating teaching modules for undergraduate courses. 


Last Modified: 04/06/2023
Modified by: Ganesh Sriram
